newsitem.title: MEXICO: Mexico stocks seen higher on carryover, peso firm.
newsitem.headline: Mexico stocks seen higher on carryover, peso firm.

text.p: --Mexico stocks seen up on follow-through, rate cuts
--Peso likely firm on capital inflow, U.S. long bond yield
--Cetes overnight rate seen down from high prior close
Dealers saw shares opening with upside potential on Wednesday due to momentum acquired from sharp gains chalked up on second quarter earnings during the prior session.

Stocks would also benefit, they said, from a 102 basis point drop in 28-day Cetes rates at Tuesday night's central bank primary auction. The benchmark rate dropped to 17.70 percent, the lowest level since the 1994 peso crisis.
Technical analysts situated resistance at 4,830 points on the IPC index, up from Tuesday's close of 4,797.49.
Traders saw the peso shrugging off the primary rate fall on capital inflow triggered by the U.S. 30-year Treasury bond, which was up 13/32 early Wednesday to yield 6.36 percent.
Dealers forecast a trading range of 7.7550/7.7850 per dollar for the 48-hour peso. Pre-open bids stood at 7.7640/7.7680 per dollar, compared to Tuesday's close of 7.7815/7.7850.
Overnight rates on Cetes were seen opening down from the prior close of 20.00 percent that had been reached after a late speculative spike, dealers said.
